pros: Mission driven and focused on teens
cons: None that I can think of

job_title: Health Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: I enjoyed the school that I was placed at in New York City. There is a nice mix of freedom and structure to the HealthCorps program. You definitely have to be comfortable building relationships and putting yourself out there.
cons: For some people, the role may feel too independent and unstructured since you have to create a lot of the structure.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Good first time job for new grads.
cons: Extra asks if you when you don’t expect them.

pros: Meaningful work, connections at school site are most valuable.
cons: The potential to feel isolated and disconnected from colleagues since work is remote.

job_title: Regional Program Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Loved the mission and outcome of work. Remote position with some field work at school or program sites. Made great connections
cons: New programming, lot of planning and building. Lacked some support.

pros: The organization's mission to focus on health and wellness in high need middle and high schools. The CEO's dedication to creating a culture of inclusion
cons: because of programming and geography, it can feel a little siloed.

review_title: Awesome place to get your start!
job_title: Regional Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Amazing start for a variety of career paths and industries
cons: Placements can be a bit isolating since you're not working with your fellow HealthCorps coordinators/staff however if you put in the effort to really work with your site champions, you'll build a community where you're placed!

pros: Lots of opportunities to gain different kinds of experience in health education
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for vertical movement

job_title: Healthcorps Coordinator in New York, NY

review_title: The most supportive working environment I've ever had!!
job_title: Living Labs Program Coordinator in Salinas, CA
pros: The HealthCorps team was so warm and welcoming and was always there for whatever I needed. My supervisor was wonderful and even though the position was remote, I felt as though I could always call on her for advice and support. The trainings were some of my favorite weeks on the job. They were a great place to meet with other coordinators from across the country and discuss best practices and I always returned to my school refreshed. The culture of the organization promoted serious hard work yet fun at the same time. I'd recommend this position to anyone who is eager to make change, driven, silly and warm-hearted.
cons: I did not receive much constructive criticism throughout my position with Healthcorps. I asked for more performance reviews than were scheduled and I often received lots of praise but rarely any advice on how I could  improve—and I'm sure there was plenty upon which I could improve. I feel I would have been a better asset to HealthCorps and to my school if I'd had someone telling me about my opportunities for growth.

pros: I can't think of any honestly.
cons:
If you're a sorority girl, this job is perfect for you. Just picture typical fake happy blonde atmosphere - for orientation, trainings, and monthly meetings.

This is a typical entry level job where it seems they take kids who have just graduated college and don't know whether they want to go back to school and can't find a job they want just yet so they pretend it's this AMAZING company and you get to "Meet Dr. Oz!" when it is really just a company who doesn't do much - it's a face for Dr Oz to look good. In the only meeting where we actually got to meet Dr. Oz the CFO prepped us for him coming in and called us "volunteers". Like, I get it, he gets paid a lot for what he does - but to call us volunteers when we are the ones working every day in school was rude. 

Also, pay is poopy.

pros: You will be given loads of flexibility & guidance to positively impact communities. Supervisors are understanding and supportive. Coordinator cohort becomes family-like even while being thousands of miles away from one another. HealthCorps is a truly unique experience.
cons: The lack of on-site direction can be difficult to understand what/how to make programming possible at your school site, since most program supervisors are not local to your area & rarely visit faraway sites. The job can be lonely if you do not seek out allies in health at your school site.

pros: Connections with students, social sector impact, changing communities, project based work, time-off,  lots of free food, autonomy, great place for future doctors
cons: Finding true balance & pay. Working for HC is truly a great experience. The staff, leadership, and coordinators are all amazing people who are passionate about changing lives.

review_title: HealthCorps Coordinator position - work in a high school teaching students about health
pros: Create your own program, opportunity to pursue your interests, helping students, lots of interaction with other Coordinators
cons: Required a lot of one's own time to complete all tasks

job_title: Healthcorps Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Great company that stood for great things!
cons: Sometimes out of work commitments kept me from being in my school.

review_title: HealthCorps prepared me for a career in Public Health Community Health Education
